title: It's been two months, so why don't I feel any better?

turns.content:
It's been two months, so why don't I feel any better?

About two months ago, my nearly six-year-long relationship ended. It was ugly and it was painful. But I'm doing it right. No contact. New apartment. 4 weeks into SL 5x5 and kicking ass. Got a new job, enrolled in 17 hours of classes this semester, expanding my social circles, reconnecting with old friends, breaking shitty old habits, and adopting a slew of good new ones. By any standard, I'm doing great.


Except I can't really get her off my mind. I stay busy. I read, I write, I hang out with people. But in the moments during the page turn, or the clicking of the mechanical pencil, or the lull in conversation during dinner, there she is. She's there after I turn off the light, there in my dreams, and I wake up in a panic wondering where I am and where she is. Literally every damn day.


Every victory of the last two months (and I'm indescribably proud of how many there have been) is punctuated by how proud I think she'd be. I'm trying not to dwell. I'm not dwelling, really. I'm being ambushed, and the weeks since have done nothing to decrease the sense of loss.


I know I'm brokenhearted. I've been here before. But it doesn't seem to be getting better. What do?

EDIT: I need to put my head down, stay the course, and do the hard, painful work while everything hurts anyway.

I just have this sense of yet more lost time to go. I want so badly to move on with my life. The last several months of the relationship itself were so goddamn destructive and pointless, I really hate the idea of being held back still in such a fundamental way.

The past can be such a morass of regret and misery that I try to avoid considering it more than is necessary. I think what I'm so bothered by is that intellectually, I've got this thing figured out. What happened, what to do now, and whenever the time comes, a pretty solid idea of what and what not to do next time around.

The entire emotional experience is beyond my conscious control. That's cool too. That shit is basic, primitive, built into the hardware itself. Different juices squirt around in my brain and I feel different things before I've had the opportunity to even apply anything cognitive to it.

Its always a choice, and I've been choosing well. The more a habit I make of it, the better position I'll be in and habits I'll have when I finally pull my head out of my ass and stop living so mechanically. Thanks for helping me realize that I'm okay. I'm doing better than well, even if it doesn't feel like it.

This is an incredibly powerful share, and first, I want to pause and sincerely acknowledge the monumental effort you have put in over the last two months.

You are not just surviving; you are **thriving** by external metrics. New job, new home, 5x5, 17 hours of classes, expanding social circles—that is an almost inhuman level of proactive, positive change. You should be indescribably proud, and the fact that you have achieved all of this *while* managing intense heartache speaks volumes about your strength and commitment to your future.

Let’s talk about why it doesn't feel better.

---

### 1. Two Months Is Not a Timeline for Six Years

You are questioning why you don’t feel better after two months. Let’s reframe that. You spent **six years** building a life, a routine, an identity, and a deep chemical attachment with one person.

Two months is the acute phase of withdrawal. Your brain is still adjusting to the sudden absence of a fundamental part of its operating system. If you were healing from a major physical injury that took six years to develop, two months would barely cover the initial stabilization phase.

The timeline for genuinely feeling "over" a deep, long-term relationship is often measured in many more months, sometimes a year or more. The fact that you are functioning at this high level after only eight weeks is frankly astonishing. You are not behind schedule; you are sprinting through a marathon.

### 2. The Difference Between Distraction and Processing

You are a master of distraction—and that is a necessary and healthy survival tool right now. You are filling every gap with productive, positive action.

The problem, as you’ve identified, is that the emotional work doesn't care about your schedule.

> "But in the moments during the page turn, or the clicking of the mechanical pencil, or the lull in conversation during dinner, there she is."

These are the moments when your brain finally gets a break from the focused, cognitive tasks (job, school, lifting) and the primitive, emotional hardware kicks in. This isn't dwelling; this is **processing**. You can’t schedule grief, but you can’t avoid it either. It ambushes you because your conscious mind is too busy "doing well" to sit down and process the loss of six years.

### 3. The "Ambush" of Success

This observation is profoundly painful and incredibly insightful:

> "Every victory of the last two months... is punctuated by how proud I think she'd be."

This happens because, for six years, she was your primary audience, your default cheerleader, and the person whose opinion mattered most regarding your personal growth. Your brain has wired the feeling of success to her validation.

You are literally rebuilding the internal reward system of your brain. You are teaching yourself that *your* pride, *your* satisfaction, and *your* new social circle’s approval are the new, valid source of reward. This rewiring takes time, repetition, and consistency.

### 4. You’ve Already Found the Answer

In your edit, you articulated the entire situation perfectly:

> "The entire emotional experience is beyond my conscious control. That's cool too. That shit is basic, primitive, built into the hardware itself... Its always a choice, and I've been choosing well."

You have intellectually mastered the distinction between the cognitive brain and the primitive, emotional brain.

*   **Cognitive Brain:** This is the part running your life, enrolling in 17 hours of classes, and hitting PRs in the gym. It knows what to do, what happened, and what not to do next time. It is operating flawlessly.
*   **Emotional Brain (The Hardware):** This is the part dealing with the chemical shock of separation, the loss of attachment, and the trauma of the "goddamn destructive and pointless" ending. It is messy, chaotic, and operates on a much slower timeline.

Your choice is not whether to *feel* the pain—that’s automatic. Your choice is what you **do** with the pain. And you are choosing well, every single day, by putting your head down, staying the course, and doing the hard work.

### What to "Do" Now

You are already doing everything right. The only thing you might need to adjust is your expectation of the emotional timeline.

1.  **Acknowledge the Pain as a Sign of Health:** The intensity of the pain reflects the depth of the commitment you had. It is proof that you are human, that you loved deeply, and that you are actively grieving a massive loss.
2.  **Be Kind to the "Ambushed" Self:** When she pops up after you turn off the light, instead of fighting the thought or feeling panic, try a brief moment of gentle acknowledgment. "There she is. That's the grief for the six years. It hurts. Okay. Now, back to my breathing." You don't have to dwell, but resisting the emotion often makes it stronger.
3.  **Trust the Mechanical Process:** You feel mechanical right now because you are building new emotional pathways through sheer force of will and habit. That mechanical feeling *is* the process of laying down the new neural concrete. The feelings will eventually catch up to the actions. You are creating the foundation for future, authentic happiness, even if you can’t feel it yet.

You are not being held back. You are in the crucible of transformation. The pain doesn't mean you are failing; it means you are actively, powerfully healing. Keep choosing well. You are doing better than well.
